TI FLUCTUATIONS AND SQUEEZING IN ONE-MODE AND 2-MODE OF 2 COUPLED
   OSCILLATORS
SO NUOVO CIMENTO DELLA SOCIETA ITALIANA DI FISICA B-GENERAL PHYSICS
   RELATIVITY ASTRONOMY AND MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS AND METHODS
LA English
DT Article
ID STATES; LIGHT; FIELD
AB The investigation of one- and two-mode quantum fluctuations and squeezing in coupled oscillators is a current matter in the recent literature. The coupling model Hamiltonian has the usual form V = i ($) over bar h gamma(alpha(1) alpha(2) - alpha(1)(dagger) alpha(2)(dagger)), where alpha(i), alpha(i)(dagger), are the traditional ladder operators. Here we will extend this model by including the interaction Hamiltonian V' = i ($) over bar h gamma'(alpha(1) alpha(2)(dagger) - alpha(1)(dagger) alpha(2) ) to investigate those fluctuations in the scenery of two coupled oscillators in the controlled presence of the RWA terms. Particular cases in the literature are obtained from this extended model for gamma much greater than gamma', gamma much less than gamma' and gamma = gamma'. For arbitrary values of gamma and, gamma' we obtain exact results for fluctuations in quadrature-phase amplitudes, for one- and two-mode oscillations, which are exhibited in several plots for different values of the involved parameters.
C1 UNIV FED PARAIBA,CCEN,DEPT FIS,BR-58059900 JOAO PESSOA,PARAIBA,BRAZIL.

TI TIME-OF-FLIGHT TECHNIQUE TO DETERMINE TEMPERATURE OF ATOMS IN A
   RING-SHAPED TRAP
SO OPTICS COMMUNICATIONS
LA English
DT Note
ID MAGNETOOPTICAL TRAP; NEUTRAL ATOMS; DOPPLER LIMIT; LASER; BEHAVIOR
AB Spatial ring-shaped distribution of atoms in magneto-optical traps can be produced when the Gaussian laser beams used in the trap are misaligned as in a race-track geometry, We use a new version of the time of flight technique to determine the temperature and velocity distribution of the atoms in the ring, We found results which are consistent with the Doppler theory of laser cooling.
C1 UNIV FED ALAGOAS,MACEIO,SP,BRAZIL.
   CTR SCI ORSAY,INST OPT,CNRS,UNITE ASSOCIEE,ORSAY,FRANCE.

TI BOUND, UNBOUND OPERATORS AND THE SQUEEZING EFFECT
SO NUOVO CIMENTO DELLA SOCIETA ITALIANA DI FISICA B-GENERAL PHYSICS
   RELATIVITY ASTRONOMY AND MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS AND METHODS
LA English
DT Article
ID JOSEPHSON-PARAMETRIC AMPLIFIER; JAYNES-CUMMINGS MODEL; SPIN STATES;
   STATISTICS; NOISE; LIGHT
AB In this paper we report the difference between the squeezing effect for quadrature operators (describing a photon field or harmonic oscillator) and for spin variables (describing a two-level system), the distinction coming from the bound and unbound character of the operators involved in the definition of squeezing for each system.

TI INTENSITY DEPENDENCE OF OPTICAL SUPPRESSION IN PHOTOASSOCIATIVE
   IONIZATION COLLISIONS IN A SODIUM MAGNETOOPTIC TRAP
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW A
LA English
DT Note
ID LASER MODIFICATION; ATOMS
AB We report the intensity dependence of photoassociative ionization collisions in a sodium magneto-optic trap (MOT). A suppressor beam with frequency tuned 600 MHz to the blue of the MOT trapping transition reduces the rate constant of the inelastic process by as much as a factor of 20 at an intensity of 8 W cm(-2). A comparison with theory shows good agreement.

TI PROBING A QUANTUM STATE VIA ELECTRONIC DEFLECTION
SO PHYSICS LETTERS A
LA English
DT Article
ID ATOMS; STATISTICS; LIGHT
AB We extend recent investigations, where a quantum state of the radiation field is probed via atomic deflection, to the case of electronic deflection. Setting a convenient configuration of field and prescriptions on the electron beam one finds an analogy between the atom and electron deflection experiments. Similarities and differences of strategy and results are discussed.

TI TIME-DEPENDENT HAMILTONIAN - SQUEEZING EFFECTS IN PARTICLE TRAPPING BY

DT Article
ID COHERENT STATES; LIGHT
AB We employ a model by Lewis and Riesenfeld (J. Math. Phys. 10, 1458 (1969)) for a time-dependent Hamiltonian and a time-dependent canonical transformation to investigate generation of squeezing effects in particle trapping by oscillating fields.

TI SCATTERING OF ATOMS BY LIGHT - PROBING A QUANTUM STATE AND THE VARIANCE
   OF THE PHASE OPERATOR
SO PHYSICS LETTERS A
LA English
DT Article
ID FIELD
AB An experiment is proposed to study the quantum state and the variance of the phase operator by measuring the momentum distribution of the atoms resulting from the interaction of an atomic beam with a single mode electromagnetic field via a two-photon interaction. A comparison of the results with those obtained for a one-photon interaction is made. Advantages in using the two-photon interaction are pointed out.

TI OPTICAL SUPPRESSION OF PHOTOASSOCIATIVE IONIZATION IN A MAGNETOOPTICAL
   TRAP
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID LASER MODIFICATION; COLLISIONS; ATOMS
AB We demonstrate suppression of two-color photoassociative ionization in a sodium vapor magneto-optical trap by imposing an auxiliary ''suppressor'' light beam on the ensemble of colliding trapped atoms. We interpret the experimental results in terms of a simple picture in which the suppressor light intercepts incoming reactant particle flux and reroutes it to long-range repulsive states, effectively preventing further approach of the collision pairs.

TI FORCES ACTING ON MAGNETOOPTICALLY TRAPPED ATOMS
SO JOURNAL OF THE OPTICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA B-OPTICAL PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article
ID NEUTRAL ATOMS; VAPOR-CELL; SODIUM; BEHAVIOR
AB We investigated how the size of ring-shaped clouds of cold, magneto-optically trapped sodium atoms depends on the trapping parameters: magnetic-field gradient and laser intensity, detuning, and misalignment. The experiments were carried out in the low-density regime (N < 10(6) atoms), and the ring radius was shown to be independent of the number of trapped atoms. The results are explained with a simple model including a coordinate-dependent vortex force and the usual magneto-optical trap forces.

TI DYNAMICAL STABILIZATION - A NEW MODEL FOR SUPERMOLASSES
SO OPTICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID OPTICAL MOLASSES; ATOMS; TRAP; FORCE
AB We present an analytical treatment of the force on a two-level atom interacting with a three-dimensional optical molasses. We show that, for small misalignment of the molasses light fields, corresponding to the so-called supermolasses configuration, there can be a dynamically induced stabilization of the atomic motion. This stabilization increases the time required for the atom to diffuse out of the molasses region and therefore provides a novel explanation of experimental observations. We describe the stabilization effect by analogy with the stabilization of the Kapitza pendulum, which is subject to a harmonic modulation of the pendulum pivot point.

TI LONG-RANGE MOLECULAR-STATES AND ULTRACOLD PHOTOASSOCIATIVE IONIZATION
   COLLISIONS
SO LASER PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article
AB We discuss two aspects of photoassociative ionization in a sodium magnetooptical trap:  (1) interpretation of free-bound peak structures in terms of pure long-range molecular states and (2) comparison of the measured line shape for two-color photoassociative ionization to a prediction based on the quasi-static theory of collision broadening.  It is concluded that hyperfine molecular states play a critical role in photoassociation dynamics at long range.

TI ANISOTROPY INVESTIGATIONS AND PHOTOLUMINESCENCE PROPERTIES OF POROUS
   SILICON
SO SOLID STATE COMMUNICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID LUMINESCENCE; RECOMBINATION; MECHANISM; SILOXENE
AB Porous silicon layers have been investigated using reflectance and photoluminescence techniques at room and liquid nitrogen temperatures. We observe a noticeable anisotropy of porous silicon samples. The measured parallel and normal components of the refractive index for samples with moderate porosity were 1.25 and 1.30, respectively. Possible mechanisms for the origin of the photoluminescence are discussed.

TI NONLOCAL POTENTIALS AS GENERATORS OF SQUEEZING
SO PHYSICS LETTERS A
LA English
DT Article
ID STATES
AB Exploring the equivalence between a nonlocal potential and a velocity-dependent potential we show how to construct a nonlocal potential which is able to generate the squeezing effect. In this scheme it is shown that, while the coherence comes from the diagonal part of the nonlocal potential V(x, x'), the squeezing effect emerges from its off-diagonal part. A brief discussion of the results is given.

TI NORMAL-ORDERING TECHNIQUE TO SOLVE THE CHARGED OSCILLATOR IN A
   TIME-DEPENDENT MAGNETIC-FIELD
SO NUOVO CIMENTO DELLA SOCIETA ITALIANA DI FISICA B-GENERAL PHYSICS
   RELATIVITY ASTRONOMY AND MATHEMATICAL PHYSICS AND METHODS
LA English
DT Article
ID SQUEEZED STATES; GENERATION; MASS
AB We employ the Schrodinger picture and the normal-ordering technique to investigate the generation of squeezing for a charged oscillator in the presence of a time-dependent magnetic field. As previous results in the literature obtained for constant magnetic fields (static case), we show that our extended system may also evolve to a squeezed state out of a coherent state. Expressions for variances in quadrature components are quite general, the amount of squeezing depending on the specification of the functional time-dependence of the magnetic field. The result for the static case is obtained as a particularization of ours.

TI PARTICLE TRAPPING BY OSCILLATING FIELDS - REGIONS OF INSTABILITY IN
   QUANTUM FLUCTUATIONS
SO QUANTUM OPTICS
LA English
DT Article
AB In a previous paper we studied squeezing of mechanical motion for a particle trapped in oscillating fields. We considered a model proposed by Glauber and time-dependent transformations to show that the system may exhibit quantum fluctuations below the shot noise level. Here we pursue this investigation to discuss the regions of instability, where for a certain range of parameters, variance of quadrature phase amplitudes continues to grow with time.

TI SPATIAL-DISTRIBUTION OF ATOMS IN A MAGNETOOPTICAL TRAP
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW A
LA English
DT Article
ID NEUTRAL ATOMS; SODIUM ATOMS; SPECTROSCOPY; BEHAVIOR; LOSSES
AB We present a theoretical analysis to explain the origin of different spatial distributions of laser-cooled sodium atoms in a magneto-optical trap. Such distributions, which include spherical clouds, rings, and rings with cores, are attributed to the radiation pressure due to misaligned Gaussian beams acting on each individual atom. The predictions of this theory are confirmed by experimental observations reported earlier. We were able to construct a diagram with several domains corresponding to the stable structures observed.

TI NARROW RESONANCES OBSERVED WITH NEARLY DEGENERATE LIGHT IN AN OPEN
   2-LEVEL SYSTEM
SO OPTICS LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID RAMSEY FRINGES
AB We report the observation of narrow resonances in the optical region by using the method of separated oscillatory fields in an atomic beam. Because of optical pumping, two nearly degenerate optical fields create a time-dependent modulation of the ground-state population, which interferes with the optical fields in a second region, resulting in a fringe pattern. The width and shape of the observed fringes are the same as those observed with the usual Ramsey method, although no coherence between the two levels under investigation is needed.

TI DETERMINATION OF POROUS SILICON FILM PARAMETERS BY POLARIZED-LIGHT
   REFLECTANCE MEASUREMENTS
SO THIN SOLID FILMS
LA English
DT Article; Proceedings Paper
CT 1ST INTERNATIONAL CONF ON SPECTROSCOPIC ELLIPSOMETRY
CY JAN 11-14, 1993
CL MINIST RECH & ESPACE, PARIS, FRANCE
SP MINIST EDUC NATL & CULTURE FRANCE, MINIST RECH & ESPACE, CNRS, UNIV PIERRE & MARIE CURIE, DIRECT RECH ETUDES & TECH, INSTRUMENTS S A, DIV JOBIN YVON
HO MINIST RECH & ESPACE
ID QUANTUM
AB A simple method of uniaxial anisotropic media investigation by the measurement of s- and p-polarized light reflectances near normal and grazing angles as well as at the Brewster angle is proposed. The method is applied to thick films of porous silicon, the new potentially promising microelectronic material. Our results support the hypothesis of a rather high uniaxial optical anisotropy of the refractive index of porous silicon films of moderate porosity. As an illustrative example, the theoretical relationship between measurable birefringence (anisotropy) and the porosity of thin porous films with different structural morphologies as a function of the geometrical shape of the pores is presented.

TI ULTRACOLD PHOTOASSOCIATIVE IONIZATION COLLISIONS IN A MAGNETOOPTICAL
   TRAP - THE OPTICAL-FIELD-INTENSITY DEPENDENCE IN A RADIATIVELY
   DISSIPATIVE ENVIRONMENT
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW A
LA English
DT Note
ID ASSOCIATIVE IONIZATION; LASER MODIFICATION; SODIUM ATOMS
AB We report here measurements of two-body associative-ionization collisions between sodium atoms confined in a magneto-optic trap. These collisions represent a kind of ''open'' or dissipative collision for which the energy of the atom plus applied light field subsystem need not be conserved due to spontaneous-emission coupling to the vacuum modes of the radiation field. The experiment measures the photoassociative-ionization-rate constant as a function of the optical field intensity from about 40 to 260 mW cm-2. These results are in reasonable agreement with the predictions of an optical-Bloch-equation theory [Y. B. Band and P. S. Julienne, Phys. Rev. A 46, 330 (1992)], but differ strongly from the predictions of a local-equilibrium theory (A. Gallagher, Phys. Rev. A 44, 4249 (1991)].
C1 NATL INST STAND & TECHNOL, DIV MOLEC PHYS, GAITHERSBURG, MD 20899 USA.
   BEN GURION UNIV NEGEV, DEPT CHEM, IL-84105 BEER SHEVA, ISRAEL.

TI HYDROGENATED AMORPHOUS-SILICON FILMS BY 60 HZ GLOW-DISCHARGE DEPOSITION
SO JOURNAL OF APPLIED PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article
ID A-SI-H; FREQUENCY; TRANSPORT; PLASMA
AB We deposit hydrogenated amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) in a low-frequency (60 Hz) glow-discharge deposition system. The films show electronic and optical properties nearly equivalent to those of films produced by the conventional radio-frequency (13.56-MHz) glow-discharge technique. The optimal substrate temperature for the low-frequency glow-discharge technique is 150-170-degrees-C, about 100-degrees-C lower than at radio frequency. We report measurements of film properties including dark conductivity, photoconductivity, ambipolar diffusion length, infrared absorption, optical band gap, and deep defect density.

TI COLLISIONAL LOSS RATE IN A MAGNETOOPTICAL TRAP FOR SODIUM ATOMS -
   LIGHT-INTENSITY DEPENDENCE
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW A
LA English
DT Note
ID COLD
AB We have measured the total collisional loss rate for ultracold sodium atoms held in a magneto-optical trap (MOT) as a function of light intensity in the trap. We extract the rate constant for collisional loss by measuring the temporal behavior of MOT loading from background vapor. The loss rate increases with light intensity in satisfactory agreement with new calculations, which are also presented. The results are interpreted in terms of detailed collision processes.

TI LAPAROSCOPIC CHOLEDOCHOSCOPY AND CHOLEDOCHOLITHOTOMY
SO SURGICAL LAPAROSCOPY & ENDOSCOPY
LA English
DT Article
DE CHOLEDOCHOLITHIASIS; CHOLEDOCHOSCOPY; CHOLEDOCHOTOMY;
   CHOLEDOCHOLITHOTOMY; LAPAROSCOPY
ID CHOLECYSTECTOMY
AB Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is rapidly replacing traditional cholecystectomy as the treatment of choice for patients with cholelithiasis. Complications of cholelithiasis are likewise being treated laparoscopically. Choledocholithiasis represents a major challenge for the laparoscopic surgeon. This report is of the early experience with laparoscopy as the primary treatment of common bile duct stones. Two methods are described: (a) transcystic duct choledochoscopy and (b) laparoscopic choledochotomy. Twenty-two patients were encountered with choledocholithiasis (4.8% of total cholecystectomies). Successful laparoscopic choledocholithotomy was performed in 18 cases (82%). Techniques and options are discussed.
C1 SURG CLIN HATTIESBURG,HATTIESBURG,MS.

TI 2-COLOR SPECTROSCOPY OF COLLIDING ULTRACOLD ATOMS
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW LETTERS
LA English
DT Article
ID ASSOCIATIVE IONIZATION; TRAPPED SODIUM; COLLISIONS
AB We present experimental results of two-color photoassociative ionization (TCPAI) spectroscopy in a magneto-optical trap. A probe light beam traces out the frequency (and intensity) dependence of TCPAI. By manipulating the intensities of the trap and repumper lasers we investigate the participation of different hyperfine ground-state levels and demonstrate the conditions under which molecular bound states figure in the collision intermediate.

AU NAPOLITANO, RJ
   BAGNATO, VS
AF NAPOLITANO, RJ
   BAGNATO, VS
TI THE EFFECT OF A FLUCTUATING LASER FIELD ON THE PROCESS OF DECELERATING
   ATOMS IN THE ZEEMAN TUNING TECHNIQUE
SO JOURNAL OF MODERN OPTICS
LA English
DT Article
ID BEAM
AB We present a study on the process of atomic deceleration in the Zeeman tuning technique when a fluctuating laser is used. The characterization of the deceleration is made through the analysis of velocity trajectories (kv(z)) from integration of the averaged equation of motion obtained from the Bloch optical equations. Atomic motion described from an accelerated frame of reference aids the analysis of the process. It is shown that the capability of an atom to follow a magnetic field profile is more sensitive to amplitude than to phase fluctuations. The analysis presented here permits evaluation of laser quality beam on optical deceleration of atoms.
RP NAPOLITANO, RJ (corresponding author), USP,INST FIS & QUIM SAO CARLOS,CX POSTAL 369,BR-13560 SAO CARLOS,SP,BRAZIL.

ID BEAM; DECELERATION
AB We have demonstrated the production of an atomic beam with a very narrow velocity distribution through the use of the Zeeman tuning technique together with a stimulated Raman transition. PT J
AU CHAPLIK, AV
   IORIATTI, L
   BAGNATO, VS
AF CHAPLIK, AV
   IORIATTI, L
   BAGNATO, VS
TI LIGHT-INDUCED EFFECT ON THE DENSITY DISTRIBUTION IN A SAMPLE OF COLD
   TRAPPED ATOMS
SO APPLIED PHYSICS B-PHOTOPHYSICS AND LASER CHEMISTRY
LA English
DT Article
ID RADIATION PRESSURE
AB As it is known [1] an intense laser field can induce atom-atom interaction according to a dipole-dipole R-3 law. Such an interaction depends on the angle between light polarization and interatomic vector-position R. This angular dependence may produce an anisotropy in the spatial density distribution of the confined sample of cold atoms. We develop the main relations and apply them to the case of an atomic cloud of cold trapped neutral atoms with the density higher than or of the order of lambda-3, where lambda is the wavelength of light. The results presented here show the effect of such an interaction in a density regime of high experimental interest.
C1 NOVISIBIRSK SEMICOND PHYS,NOVOSIBIRSK 630090,USSR.

TI SQUEEZING AND ANTISQUEEZING FOR A HARMONIC-OSCILLATOR HAVING A SUDDEN
   CHANGE OF MASS
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW A
LA English
DT Note
ID TIME-DEPENDENT SYSTEMS; COHERENT STATES; INVARIANTS
AB Following a recent paper by De Brito and Baseia [Phys. Rev. A 40, 4097 (1989)], the generation of squeezing is examined for a harmonic oscillator when a sudden change of mass takes place. The correspondence of such oscillators with the radiation field and some related results, such as modulation of squeezing, are also considered.

PT J
AU Bagnato, VS
   Marcassa, LG
   Oria, M
   Surdutovich, GI

AF Bagnato, V. S.
   Marcassa, L. G.
   Oria, M.
   Surdutovich, G. I.
   Zilio, S. C.
TI Spatial Distributions of Optically Trapped Cooled Neutral Atoms
SO LASER PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article
AB We report on the observation of a variety of spatial distributions (modes) of optically cooled sodium atoms in a magneto-optical trap. These distributions include stable rings of atoms orbiting around a core, rings without cores and multi-center (up to four) patterns. The appearance of spatial modes depends on the laser beams' misalignment and a non-uniform transverse profile of the laser beams which gives rise to the emergence of vortex forces. A theoretical analysis of the equation of motion for the trapped atom verifies all the experimental observations. Orbital spatial modes of the trapped atoms may be used as "natural decelerators" of atomic motion.
C1 [Bagnato, V. S.; Marcassa, L. G.; Oria, M.; Zilio, S. C.] USP, Dept Fis & Ciencia Mat, Inst Fis & Quim Sao Carlos, BR-13560 Sao Carlos, SP, Brazil.
   [Surdutovich, G. I.] Russian Acad Sci, Inst Semicond Phys, Siberian Branch, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia.

TI BOSE-EINSTEIN CONDENSATION IN LOW-DIMENSIONAL TRAPS
SO PHYSICAL REVIEW A
LA English
DT Article
ID POLARIZED ATOMIC-HYDROGEN
AB We demonstrate the possibility of Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) of an ideal Bose gas confined by one- and two-dimensional power-law traps. One-dimensional systems display BEC in traps that are more confining than parabolic: U(x) approximately x-eta,eta < 2. Two-dimensional systems display BEC for any finite value of eta. A possible experimental configuration for a two-dimensional trap is described.
C1 MIT, DEPT PHYS, CAMBRIDGE, MA 02139 USA.

TI INFLUENCE OF ADIABATIC FOLLOWING AND OPTICAL-PUMPING IN THE PRODUCTION
   OF AN INTENSE STEADY FLUX OF SLOW ATOMS
SO JOURNAL OF THE OPTICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA B-OPTICAL PHYSICS
LA English
DT Article
ID LASER DECELERATION; RADIATION PRESSURE; BEAM; VELOCITIES
AB We present a study of adiabatic following and optical pumping effects in the process of slowing sodium atoms with the Zeeman tuning technique.  By manipulating the magnetic-field profile, atoms can be decelerated to a low magnetic field, where they are decoupled from the laser beam by being optically pumped to the F = 1 ground-state sublevel.  Using this method, we have produced an intense flux of slow atoms, with a well-controlled velocity of approximately 10(10) atoms/sec.
RP BAGNATO, VS (corresponding author), UNIV SAO PAULO,INST FIS & QUIM SAO CARLOS,DEPT FIS & CIENCIA MAT,CAIXA POSTAL 369,BR-13560 SAO CARLOS,SP,BRAZIL.

TI ADIABATIC FOLLOWING CONDITIONS FOR THE DECELERATION OF ATOMS WITH THE
   ZEEMAN TUNING TECHNIQUE
SO OPTICS COMMUNICATIONS
LA English
DT Article
ID LASER DECELERATION; BEAM
AB We present a study of the deceleration of atoms with the Zeeman tuning technique which allows us to investigate the conditions for the adiabatic following of atoms in an inhomogeneous magnetic field.  The atomic motion is described in an accelerated frame of reference and two possible solutions are found for the atomic velocity, one being stable and the other unstable.  The stability condition for the velocity imposes an upper limit for the magnetic field gradient and experimental results for this limit are presented.
